items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 9am on Friday 27th September, and for at least the next 24 hours. The forecast high tide at Great Yarmouth will restrict the Broads river system from draining out to sea. This will result in higher than normal water levels within the Broads. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 4pm today, Friday 27th September, or as the situation changes.

Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 27/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are high and rising, following 20mm of rain in only a few hours on Friday morning. Flood impacts are expected on Mill Lane Hellingly, and Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm. From 11:00 on 27/09/2024, flooding could also affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and gardens in those locations. From 14:00 on 27/09/2024, flooding could also affect fields, gardens and roads near North Street and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Only isolated showers are forecast on Friday afternoon and Saturday. The rivers should begin to fall by 17:00 on 27/09/2024 in Hellingly, and 06:00 on 28/09/2024 in Alfriston, and should return to normal by Saturday afternoon in Hellingly, and Sunday morning in Alfriston. More rain is forecast on Sunday evening into Monday 30/09/2024, which could again make property flooding possible. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 on 28/09/2024

items.description: Combe Haven
items.message: The Powdermill Stream in Crowhurst has now peaked following Friday morning's intense rain. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens of a small number of properties in Crowhurst, on Forewood Lane and near the recreation ground, between the Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. Only minimal flood impacts are expected to affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Only isolated showers are predicted for the rest of Friday and Saturday. The river should begin to fall in Crowhurst by 12:00 on 27/09/2024, and should return to normal from Friday evening. In Bulverhythe, river levels will fall much slower, and could remain higher than normal through the weekend. A month's worth of rain is possible on Sunday evening through until Monday 30/09/2024, which could increase the risk of property flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/09/2024

items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

Further flooding is possible tomorrow, as river levels are falling but remain higher than usual. Drier conditions are forecast for the remainder of Friday and Saturday but further heavy rain is forecast for Sunday. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings as necessary.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 28/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Over the last few days, we have seen heavy rainfall in the Welland Valley area. This means that the River Welland has risen, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is unlikely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 27/09/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 11am today, Friday 27th September, and for at least the next 24 hours. The forecast high tide at Great Yarmouth will restrict the Broads river system from draining out to sea. This will result in higher than normal water levels within the Broads. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards, and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 4pm today, Friday 27th September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Adur East Branch
items.message: More rain fell on Thursday than was expected. The River Adur is higher than normal, but is currently falling, slowly. Minor flooding impacts will continue to affect fields and gardens at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury, through until Friday. Only isolated showers are forecast on Friday and Saturday. The river should continue to slowly fall, returning nearer to normal by midday on Saturday 28/09/2024. More rain is forecast on Sunday evening into Monday 30/09/2024. Potentially a month's worth of rain is possible within 24 hours, which will increase flood risk and potentially cause property flooding. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/09/2024

items.description: Areas near the River Nene from Elton to Wansford
items.message: Heavy rain fell in the Nene catchment earlier this week which has caused the River Nene to rise. Low lying areas near the river are flooded and we now expect properties in Wansford and Yarwell to be affected this afternoon, Thursday 26 September 2024, onwards. Properties on London Road in Wansford and Mill Lane, Waters View and Marina Terrace in Yarwell are expected to be affected first. Further heavy rainfall is expected today and into Friday. River levels are expected to remain high. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation, and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 27/09/24, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Uck
items.message: Less rain fell overnight than was expected. River levels are still higher than normal, and rising between Uckfield and Isfield, but are not as high as they could have been. Minimal flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads, and gardens in Buxted, Uckfield, and Isfield through until Friday. Only isolated showers are forecast on Friday and Saturday. The river should begin to fall by 10:00 on 27/09/2024 in Buxted, by 13:00 on 27/09/2024 in Uckfield, and by 17:00 on 27/09/2024 in Isfield. River levels are expected to return to normal by Saturday 28/09/2024. More rain is forecast on Sunday evening into Monday 30/09/2024. Potentially a month's worth of rain could fall in 24 hours, which will increase flood risk and make property flooding possible. As a precaution, flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/09/2024

items.description: Lower Nene
items.message: Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Lower Nene area. This means that the River Nene is now rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from the morning of Friday 27 September onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
